IRS Assisted Federated Learning: A Broadband Over-the-Air Aggregation Approach

Deyou Zhang, , Ming Xiao, , Zhibo Pang, ,
Lihui Wang, and H. Vincent Poor D. Zhang and M. Xiao are with the Division of Information Science and Engineering (ISE), Royal Institute of Technology (KTH), Stockholm 10044, Sweden (email: {deyou, mingx}@kth.se). Z. Pang is with ABB Corporate Research, Västerås 72226, Sweden, and also with the Division of ISE, KTH, Stockholm 10044, Sweden (email: pang.zhibo@se.abb.com, zhibo@kth.se). L. Wang is with the Department of Production Engineering, KTH, Stockholm 10044, Sweden (email: lihui.wang@iip.kth.se). H. V. Poor is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, USA (poor@princeton.edu).
Abstract

We consider a broadband over-the-air computation empowered model aggregation approach for wireless federated learning (FL) systems and propose to leverage an intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) to combat wireless fading and noise. We first investigate the conventional node-selection based framework, where a few edge nodes are dropped in model aggregation to control the aggregation error. We analyze the performance of this node-selection based framework and derive an upper bound on its performance loss, which is shown to be related to the selected edge nodes. Then, we seek to minimize the mean-squared error (MSE) between the desired global gradient parameters and the actually received ones by optimizing the selected edge nodes, their transmit equalization coefficients, the IRS phase shifts, and the receive factors of the cloud server. By resorting to the matrix lifting technique and difference-of-convex programming, we successfully transform the formulated optimization problem into a convex one and solve it using off-the-shelf solvers. To improve learning performance, we further propose a weight-selection based FL framework. In such a framework, we assign each edge node a proper weight coefficient in model aggregation instead of discarding any of them to reduce the aggregation error, i.e., amplitude alignment of the received local gradient parameters from different edge nodes is not required. We also analyze the performance of this weight-selection based framework and derive an upper bound on its performance loss, followed by minimizing the MSE via optimizing the weight coefficients of the edge nodes, their transmit equalization coefficients, the IRS phase shifts, and the receive factors of the cloud server. Furthermore, we use the MNIST dataset for simulations to evaluate the performance of both node-selection and weight-selection based FL frameworks.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, intelligent reflecting surface, over-the-air computation, OFDM.

I Introduction

Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI), edge computing, and 5G networking have promoted the rapid proliferation of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) [1, 2]. In IIoT systems, each front-end device (e.g., sensor or camera) continuously generates a large amount of data, which often needs to be processed with AI or machine learning methods [1]. Taking the automatic sorting system as an example, the images of industrial products on assembly lines are firstly captured by multiple cameras from different angles and then uploaded to a remote server for processing and analysis. Due to the enormous data volumes and the limited transmission capability of consumer-grade cameras, such a data offloading process is time-demanding [3]. More importantly, the data from many confidential products often involve sensitive information. For example, the image of a product/object can reflect a lot of information about this product/object such as shape, color, size, etc. Thus, collecting IIoT data to a centralized server can also lead to privacy problems [4, 5].

To cope with the dual challenges of big data and privacy protection, federated learning (FL) provides a new paradigm for time-sensitive and privacy-preserving IIoT applications [3]. A typical FL-IIoT framework consisting of multiple front-end devices and a cloud server executes the following two procedures until convergence is achieved. 1) model broadcast: the cloud server broadcasts a global model to the front-end devices, each of which computes a local gradient vector leveraging its private dataset; 2) model aggregation: the front-end devices upload their computed local gradient vectors to the cloud server for aggregation. Since only model parameters rather than the raw data are uploaded to the cloud server, FL is capable of reducing communication costs and achieving privacy protection [3].

Despite the advantages of FL, the uplink model aggregation procedure is a severe bottleneck for FL training in communication overhead, particularly in wireless scenarios [6]. To alleviate this problem, several works have proposed to optimize resource allocation among the front-end devices to enhance FL learning efficiency [8, 9, 7]. However, those literatures [8, 9, 7] considered orthogonal multiple access (OMA) protocols for model aggregation, such that the required wireless resources, e.g., bandwidth, increased linearly with the number of devices involved in FL. As a result, when many front-end devices are involved in FL, the model aggregation procedure would incur excessive resource consumption [10].

To improve the communication efficiency in model aggregation, over-the-air computation (AirComp) empowered model aggregation approach has emerged [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16]. In such an approach, the devices use the same time-frequency resources to upload their local gradient vectors (or model updates) to the cloud server, which implements model aggregation by exploiting the waveform superposition property of multiple-access channels. Specifically, the first AirComp-empowered model aggregation research appeared in [11], where the authors derived two tradeoffs between communication and learning metrics and demonstrated that AirComp indeed substantially reduces the model uploading latency compared to the OMA protocols. To further reduce the uploading overhead, the authors in [12] and [13] proposed to first “sparsify” and compress the local gradient vectors and then upload them to the cloud server for model aggregation.

Although AirComp is envisioned as a scalable model aggregation paradigm, it still suffers from the “straggler” problem, i.e., the devices with poor channel conditions dominate the model aggregation error. To alleviate this problem, literatures [17, 19, 18, 20, 21] have proposed to employ intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) to enhance the channels between frond-end devices and the cloud server. As reported in [22, 23, 24], the IRS is a cost-effective technology to overcome the detrimental effect of channel fading in wireless communications. Precisely, an IRS consists of a row of passive reflecting elements, and by adjusting the phase shifts of these elements, we can control the propagation of the reflected signal, making it superpose constructively with the signal over the direct link to strengthen the received signal power [23]. Since the purpose of FL is different from that of traditional communication systems, the conventional transmit/receive/reflect designs for IRS-assisted communication systems cannot apply to the IRS-assisted FL systems, whose transmit/receive/reflect strategies need to be redesigned. The recent works in [17, 19, 18, 20, 21] show that IRSs indeed can alleviate the detrimental effect of channel fading and communication noise on model aggregation. Compared to FL systems without IRSs, considerable performance improvements were observed in these works [17, 19, 18, 20, 21].

The “multiplicative fading” effect limits the benefit of passive IRSs [25], and the straggler problem still exists in IRS-assisted FL systems [17, 19, 18, 20, 21]. As such, those state-of-the-art works also proposed to discard stragglers from model aggregation to avoid severe aggregation errors. In particular, the authors in [19, 18, 20] investigated a joint device selection and transmit/receive/passive beamforming design to enhance the FL learning performance. However, discarding devices reduces the total number of training data samples, which inevitably compromises the performance of FL, particularly when the discarded devices possess unique features.

To avoid this dilemma, instead of discarding any front-end devices (termed edge nodes below), we assign each of them a carefully designed weight coefficient in model aggregation to control the aggregation error. In other words, amplitude alignment of the received local gradient parameters from different edge nodes is not required, which is different from those state-of-the-art works [19, 18, 20]. Moreover, since future communication systems are wideband, we thus propose to implement model aggregation over broadband channels, which is also different from [19, 18, 20]. A detailed comparison between our work and [19, 18, 20] is provided in Table I. The contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

1) Focusing on IRS-assisted FL systems, we consider the broadband AirComp-empowered model aggregation approach. We first study the conventional node-selection based FL framework, where a few edge nodes are dropped in model aggregation to control the aggregation error. We theoretically analyze the convergence performance of this node-selection based framework and derive an upper bound on its performance loss, i.e., the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss, which is shown to be related to the selected edge nodes.

2) Subsequently, we minimize the mean-squared error (MSE) between the desired aggregated gradient vector and the actually received one by optimizing edge node selection, transceiver design, and IRS configuration, which is a highly intractable combinatorial optimization problem. By using the matrix lifting technique and difference-of-convex (DC) programming, we successfully transform the original intractable optimization problem into a convex one and solve it using off-the-shelf solvers.

3) To avoid a noticeable decrease in the learning performance caused by node selection, we further propose a weight-selection based FL framework. In such a framework, we assign each edge node a carefully designed weight coefficient in model aggregation instead of discarding any of them. As in the node-selection based framework, we analyze the performance of this weight-selection based framework and derive an upper bound on its performance loss. We also minimize the MSE by jointly optimizing the weight coefficients of the edge nodes, their transmit equalization coefficients, the IRS phase shifts, and the receive factors of the cloud server.

4) We use the MNIST dataset for simulations to evaluate the performance of both node-selection and weight-selection based FL frameworks. Simulation results show that the IRS indeed alleviates the straggler problem, and the weight-selection based framework achieves higher prediction accuracy than its node-selection based counterpart.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces preliminaries about FL, the node-selection based FL framework, the IRS-assisted communication model, and the AirComp-empowered model aggregation. Section III analyzes the convergence of the node-selection based FL framework. Section IV describes how to optimize the selected edge nodes, their transmit equalization coefficients, the IRS phase shifts, and the receive factors of the cloud server to minimize the model aggregation error of the node-selection based FL framework. We develop the weight-selection based FL framework in Section V. Simulation results are provided in Section VI, and this paper concludes in Section VII. The major notations used in the article are listed in Table II.

II System Model

In this section, we develop an AirComp-empowered model aggregation approach for FL, and an IRS is employed to enhance the wireless transmissions.

II-A Preliminaries of FL

II-B Node-Selection Based FL Systems

In FL systems, the model parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} is computed in an iterative manner between the cloud server and the K𝐾K edge nodes, which is repeated for a fixed number of L𝐿L rounds or until a global consensus is achieved. Precisely, the l𝑙l-th round of a conventional FL system consists of the following procedure.

Model broadcast: The cloud server broadcasts the current global model parameter vector 𝒘[l]superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙\bm{w}^{[l]} to the K𝐾K edge nodes, as depicted in Fig. 1(a).

Local gradient computation: Based on the received global model 𝒘[l]superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙\bm{w}^{[l]}, edge node k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in{\cal K} leverages its own dataset to compute a local gradient vector, given by

𝒈k[l]=∇Fk​(𝒘[l]).superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘delimited-[]𝑙∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙{\bm{g}}_{k}^{[l]}=\nabla F_{k}\left(\bm{w}^{[l]}\right).

Edge node selection: The cloud server selects a subset of the K𝐾K edge nodes, denoted by 𝒮[l]⊆𝒦superscript𝒮delimited-[]𝑙𝒦{\cal S}^{[l]}\subseteq{\cal K}, to participate in the subsequent model aggregation procedure. In the sequel, we term the edge nodes in 𝒮[l]superscript𝒮delimited-[]𝑙{\cal S}^{[l]} active edge nodes at the l𝑙l-th training round.

Model aggregation: As shown in Fig. 1(b), the selected edge nodes upload their respectively computed local gradient vectors to the cloud server, which takes an average of these local gradient vectors to update the global model parameter vector, given by

𝒈[l]=1|𝒮[l]|​∑k∈𝒮[l]𝒈k[l],superscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑙1superscript𝒮delimited-[]𝑙subscript𝑘superscript𝒮delimited-[]𝑙superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\displaystyle\bm{g}^{[l]}=\frac{1}{\left|{\cal S}^{[l]}\right|}\sum\limits_{k\in{\cal S}^{[l]}}{\bm{g}}_{k}^{[l]}, (5)
𝒘[l+1]=𝒘[l]−η[l]​𝒈[l],superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙1superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙superscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑙\displaystyle\bm{w}^{[l+1]}=\bm{w}^{[l]}-\eta^{[l]}{\bm{g}}^{[l]}, (6)

where η[l]superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙\eta^{[l]} is the learning rate.

II-C Broadband Transmission

To cope with frequency selective fading and the resultant inter-symbol interference, orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) is adopted for uplink transmission from edge nodes to the cloud server. Without loss of generality, we assume that the whole bandwidth is divided into N𝑁N sub-channels, which are also referred to as sub-carriers.

II-D IRS-Assisted Communication

The underlying wireless communication network for the aforementioned FL system is illustrated in Fig. 2, where an IRS is deployed to assist in the communications between the cloud server and the K𝐾K edge nodes.

II-E AirComp-Empowered Model Aggregation

To reduce the total access delay, we adopt AirComp for model aggregation. That is, every selected edge node occupies all the N𝑁N sub-channels to upload its computed local gradient parameters to the cloud server in model aggregation. By properly controlling the transmit equalization coefficients of the active edge nodes and the receive factors of the cloud server, a noisy version of the desired global gradient vector (5) can be constructed, as detailed below.

First of all, we compute the first-order and second-order statistics of each local gradient vector by

In other words, by using g¯k[l]superscriptsubscript¯𝑔𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\bar{g}_{k}^{[l]} and δk[l]superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\delta_{k}^{[l]}, we map [𝒈k[l]]isubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘delimited-[]𝑙𝑖\big{[}\bm{g}_{k}^{[l]}\big{]}_{i} to a zero-mean unit-variance symbol [𝒈k[l]]i−g¯k[l]δk[l]subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘delimited-[]𝑙𝑖subscriptsuperscript¯𝑔delimited-[]𝑙𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛿delimited-[]𝑙𝑘\frac{\big{[}\bm{g}_{k}^{[l]}\big{]}_{i}-\bar{g}^{[l]}_{k}}{\sqrt{\delta^{[l]}_{k}}}, which is the final transmit symbol on the uplink channel.

Recall that there are a total number of N𝑁N sub-channels that can be leveraged by the active edge nodes to upload their respective local gradient vectors, each of which consists of d𝑑d parameters. Suppose that each sub-channel conveys only one parameter at one time slot. Then, uploading all d𝑑d parameters to the cloud server will occupy T=d/N𝑇𝑑𝑁T=d/N time slots. III Convergence Analysis of Node-Selection Based FL Framework

In this section, we analyze the convergence of the node-selection based FL framework that employs IRS, OFDM, and AirComp techniques for model aggregation in each training round.

III-A Assumptions

To proceed, we first make the following assumptions as in [19, 18, 9, 28].

Assumption 1

The global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) is strongly convex w.r.t. parameter μ>0𝜇0\mu>0, such that for any 𝒙,𝒚∈ℛd𝒙𝒚superscriptℛ𝑑\bm{x},\bm{y}\in{\cal R}^{d}, we have

F​(𝒚)≥F​(𝒙)+(𝒚−𝒙)T​∇F​(𝒙)+μ2​‖𝒚−𝒙‖2.𝐹𝒚𝐹𝒙superscript𝒚𝒙𝑇∇𝐹𝒙𝜇2superscriptnorm𝒚𝒙2F(\bm{y})\geq F(\bm{x})+\left(\bm{y}-\bm{x}\right)^{T}\nabla F(\bm{x})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}. (17)
Assumption 2

The global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) has Lipschitz continuous gradient with parameter ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, such that for any 𝒙,𝒚∈ℛd𝒙𝒚superscriptℛ𝑑\bm{x},\bm{y}\in{\cal R}^{d}, we have

‖∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)‖≤ρ​‖𝒙−𝒚‖,norm∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚𝜌norm𝒙𝒚\left\|\nabla F\left(\bm{x}\right)-\nabla F\left(\bm{y}\right)\right\|\leq\rho\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|, (18)

which is equivalent to

F​(𝒚)≤F​(𝒙)+(𝒚−𝒙)T​∇F​(𝒙)+ρ2​‖𝒚−𝒙‖2.𝐹𝒚𝐹𝒙superscript𝒚𝒙𝑇∇𝐹𝒙𝜌2superscriptnorm𝒚𝒙2F(\bm{y})\leq F(\bm{x})+\left(\bm{y}-\bm{x}\right)^{T}\nabla F(\bm{x})+\frac{\rho}{2}\left\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\right\|^{2}. (19)
Assumption 3

The gradient w.r.t. any labeled data sample {𝒖k,i,vk,i}subscript𝒖𝑘𝑖subscript𝑣𝑘𝑖\{\bm{u}_{k,i},v_{k,i}\}, ∀k,ifor-all𝑘𝑖\forall k,i, is upper bounded. In other words, for some constants γ1≥0subscript𝛾10\gamma_{1}\geq 0 and γ2≥1subscript𝛾21\gamma_{2}\geq 1, we have

‖∇f​(𝒘;𝒖k,i,vk,i)‖2≤γ1+γ2​‖∇F​(𝒘)‖2.superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝒘subscript𝒖𝑘𝑖subscript𝑣𝑘𝑖2subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝒘2\big{\|}\nabla f\left(\bm{w};\bm{u}_{k,i},v_{k,i}\right)\big{\|}^{2}\leq\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}\big{\|}\nabla F(\bm{w})\big{\|}^{2}. (20)

III-C Extension to Non-Convex Loss Function

Note that the loss function can also be non-convex [29]. In this case, we use the average norm of the global gradient vector to characterize the convergence property of FL recursions, as detailed in the following theorem.

IV Communication and Node Selection Strategy Co-Design

Upon examining (29), we can observe a tradeoff between the node selection loss and the communication error loss, described by the first and second terms of (29), respectively. On the one hand, selecting more edge nodes results in a larger K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}, thereby reducing the node selection loss. On the other hand, selecting more edge nodes increases the communication error maxj∈𝒩⁡|mj[l]|2subscript𝑗𝒩superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑚delimited-[]𝑙𝑗2\max\nolimits_{j\in{\cal N}}\big{|}m^{[l]}_{j}\big{|}^{2}, which will be further elaborated in Proposition 1.

By applying the same procedures employed in proving Proposition 5 of [14], we can establish that the solution sequence generated by recursively solving P6subscriptP6{\textsf{P}}_{6} always converges to a critical point of P5subscriptP5{\textsf{P}}_{5} given an arbitrary initial point.

Finally, since the computational cost of solving P6subscriptP6{\textsf{P}}_{6} via the second-order interior point method [30] is 𝒪​([(P+1)2+K]3)𝒪superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝑃12𝐾3{\cal O}([(P+1)^{2}+K]^{3}) at each iteration, the overall computational cost of solving P3subscriptP3{\textsf{P}}_{3} is 𝒪​(I1​[(P+1)2+K]3)𝒪subscript𝐼1superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝑃12𝐾3{\cal O}(I_{1}[(P+1)^{2}+K]^{3}), where I1subscript𝐼1I_{1} is the total number of iterations before P6subscriptP6{\textsf{P}}_{6} converges.

Until now, we have introduced how to select edge nodes, design their transmit equalization coefficients, and optimize the receive factors of the cloud server and the IRS phase shifts to control the communication errors in model aggregation. In the next section, we propose a new FL framework to improve learning performance further.

V Weight-Selection Based FL Systems

As mentioned before, although node selection helps mitigate aggregation errors, dropping a few edge nodes can lead to a non-negligible decrease in the learning performance, especially when the discarded edge nodes have unique data samples.

To avoid this dilemma, instead of dropping any edge nodes in model aggregation, we assign each edge node a carefully designed weight coefficient to control the aggregation error, as shown in Fig. 1(c). In other words, instead of utilizing (6), we propose to update the global model by

𝒘[l+1]=𝒘[l]−η[l]∑j=1Kqj[l]​∑k=1Kqk[l]​𝒈k[l],superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙1superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘delimited-[]𝑙superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\bm{w}^{[l+1]}=\bm{w}^{[l]}-\frac{\eta^{[l]}}{\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{K}q^{[l]}_{j}}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}q_{k}^{[l]}{\bm{g}}_{k}^{[l]}, (42)

where qk[l]∈[0,1]superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘delimited-[]𝑙01q_{k}^{[l]}\in\left[0,1\right] is the k𝑘k-th edge node’s weight coefficient for model aggregation at the l𝑙l-th training round, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}. Notice that (42) can be viewed as a generalization of (6), and if q1[l],⋯,qK[l]superscriptsubscript𝑞1delimited-[]𝑙⋯superscriptsubscript𝑞𝐾delimited-[]𝑙q_{1}^{[l]},\cdots,q_{K}^{[l]} are restricted to be 0−1010-1 binary variables, (42) reduces to (6). In the following, we first introduce how to recover

𝒈~[l]=1∑j=1Kqj[l]​∑k=1Kqk[l]​𝒈k[l]superscriptbold-~𝒈delimited-[]𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘delimited-[]𝑙superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\bm{\tilde{g}}^{[l]}=\frac{1}{\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{K}q^{[l]}_{j}}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}q_{k}^{[l]}{\bm{g}}_{k}^{[l]} (43)

from the received signals, and then analyze the performance of such a weight-selection based FL system. At the end of this section, we discuss how to design q1[l],⋯,qK[l]superscriptsubscript𝑞1delimited-[]𝑙⋯superscriptsubscript𝑞𝐾delimited-[]𝑙q_{1}^{[l]},\cdots,q_{K}^{[l]} to achieve appealing learning performance.

V-B Convergence Analysis

Following (III-B), we also decompose the gradient error into two parts, i.e.,

Proof:

V-C Weight Coefficient Optimization

Similar to (29), we observe a tradeoff between the weight selection loss and the communication error loss, described by the first and second terms of (59), respectively. As in Section IV, we fix the weight selection loss by setting ∑k=1Kqk[l]superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘delimited-[]𝑙\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}q_{k}^{[l]} to Q0subscript𝑄0Q_{0}, ∀l=1,⋯,Lfor-all𝑙1⋯𝐿\forall l=1,\cdots,L, and only seek to minimize the communication errors by optimizing q1[l],⋯,qK[l]superscriptsubscript𝑞1delimited-[]𝑙⋯superscriptsubscript𝑞𝐾delimited-[]𝑙q_{1}^{[l]},\cdots,q_{K}^{[l]}. Below we focus on the l𝑙l-th training round and take the maximum MSE across the N𝑁N sub-channels of this round as the objective function to construct an optimization problem, given by

It is observed that P8subscriptP8{\textsf{P}}_{8} is almost the same as P3subscriptP3\textsf{P}_{3} except for replacing 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} with 𝒒𝒒\bm{q}. Therefore, we can similarly leverage the matrix lifting technique and DC programming to solve P8subscriptP8{\textsf{P}}_{8}, but for brevity, we omit the details here. Since 𝒒𝒒\bm{q} is a real vector while 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} is only a binary one, P8subscriptP8{\textsf{P}}_{8} will achieve a lower objective value than P3subscriptP3{\textsf{P}}_{3}, and we can thus infer that the weight-selection based FL framework will outperform its node-selection based counterpart.

Thus far, we have introduced the weight-selection based FL framework. We have described how to design the edge nodes’ transmit equalization coefficients, their weight coefficients, the cloud server’s receive factors, and the IRS phase shifts to control the communication errors in model aggregation. In the next section, we use experiments to evaluate the performance of the node-selection and weight-selection based FL frameworks.

VI Numerical Results

We consider a three-dimensional coordinate system, where the locations of the cloud server and the IRS are respectively set to (−50,0,10)50010\left(-50,0,10\right) meters and (0,0,10)0010\left(0,0,10\right) meters, and the K=20𝐾20K=20 edge nodes are uniformly distributed in the region of ([0,20],[−10,10],0)02010100\left([0,20],[-10,10],0\right) meters. The whole bandwidth is divided into N=10𝑁10N=10 sub-channels, and {hd,k,j}subscriptℎ𝑑𝑘𝑗\{h_{d,k,j}\}, {𝒉r,k,j}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑘𝑗\{\bm{h}_{r,k,j}\}, and {𝒛j}subscript𝒛𝑗\{\bm{z}_{j}\} suffer from both path loss and small scale fading. The path loss model is expressed as PL​(ζ)=C0​(ζ/ζ0)−κPL𝜁subscript𝐶0superscript𝜁subscript𝜁0𝜅\textsf{PL}(\zeta)=C_{0}\left(\zeta/\zeta_{0}\right)^{-\kappa}, where C0=30subscript𝐶030C_{0}=30 dB accounts for the path loss at the reference distance of ζ0=1subscript𝜁01\zeta_{0}=1 meter, ζ𝜁\zeta denotes the link distance, and κ𝜅\kappa is the path loss component. Following [19], the path loss components for {hd,k,j}subscriptℎ𝑑𝑘𝑗\{h_{d,k,j}\}, {𝒉r,k,j}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑘𝑗\{\bm{h}_{r,k,j}\}, and {𝒛j}subscript𝒛𝑗\{\bm{z}_{j}\}, are respectively set to 3.6, 2.8 and 2.2. The small-scale fading coefficients are assumed to follow the Rician distribution, given by

χ1+χ​𝟏+11+χ​𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,𝑰),𝜒1𝜒111𝜒𝒞𝒩0𝑰\sqrt{\frac{\chi}{1+\chi}}{\bm{1}}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\chi}}{\cal CN}(\bm{0},\bm{I}),

where χ𝜒\chi is termed the Rician factor. As in [19], the Rician factors for {hd,k,j}subscriptℎ𝑑𝑘𝑗\{h_{d,k,j}\}, {𝒉r,k,j}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑘𝑗\{\bm{h}_{r,k,j}\}, and {𝒛j}subscript𝒛𝑗\{\bm{z}_{j}\} are respectively set to 0, 0, and 3 dB. Moreover, we set SNR=60SNR60\textsf{SNR}=60 dB, P=20𝑃20P=20, and O=1𝑂1O=1 unless otherwise specified.

In regards to the learning purpose, we use the MNIST dataset [32] to simulate the handwritten digit recognition task. Specifically, by using cross-entropy as the loss function, we train a fully connected neural network consisting of 784 inputs and 10 outputs, i.e., the number of model parameters d=7840𝑑7840d=7840. The training set of 60,000 samples is equally divided into 20 shards of size D=3000𝐷3000D=3000 in a non-IID manner, and each shard is assigned to one edge node as its local dataset. The test dataset has 10,000 different samples and we adopt test accuracy, defined as # of correctly recognized handwritten-digits10000∈[0,1]# of correctly recognized handwritten-digits1000001\frac{\text{\# of correctly recognized handwritten-digits}}{10000}\in[0,1], to evaluate the FL learning performance. The total number of training rounds L𝐿L is set to 100, and the learning rate η[l]=0.01superscript𝜂delimited-[]𝑙0.01\eta^{[l]}=0.01, ∀l∈{1,⋯,L}for-all𝑙1⋯𝐿\forall l\in\{1,\cdots,L\}. Furthermore, the following baselines are used for comparison in the simulations.

1) Ideal baseline: All the K𝐾K edge nodes are selected with qk[l]=1subscriptsuperscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙𝑘1q^{[l]}_{k}=1, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}, and the cloud server receives 1K​∑k=1K𝒈k[l]1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑙𝑘\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\bm{g}}^{[l]}_{k}, in an error-free manner.

2) All-node selection: All the K𝐾K edge nodes are selected with qk[l]=1subscriptsuperscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙𝑘1q^{[l]}_{k}=1, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in{\cal K}, but the cloud server receives a noisy version of 1K​∑k=1K𝒈k[l]1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝒈delimited-[]𝑙𝑘\frac{1}{K}\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}{\bm{g}}^{[l]}_{k}.

3) IRS-free channel: Edge nodes communicate directly with the cloud server without the aid of the IRS.

4) SDR: In this scheme, the SDR method [33] is applied to solve P8subscriptP8{\textsf{P}}_{8}, which is introduced to validate the effectiveness of the proposed DC algorithm.

The test accuracy w.r.t. FL training round is shown in Fig. 3. From this figure, we immediately observe that without the aid of the IRS, the all-node selection scheme performs poorly. In contrast, with the aid of the IRS, the performance of the all-node selection scheme improves significantly, demonstrating the great potential of introducing IRS to FL systems. We can also observe from this figure that the weight-selection based framework achieves a better performance than its node-selection based counterpart, and both frameworks exhibit enhanced performance compared to the all-node selection scheme. Furthermore, we also observe that the proposed DC algorithm is superior to the SDR method in optimizing the IRS configuration, thereby leading to improved FL performance.

Fig. 4 illustrates the test accuracy (after L=100𝐿100L=100 training rounds) w.r.t. K0​(Q0)subscript𝐾0subscript𝑄0K_{0}(Q_{0}). As depicted, an increase in K0​(Q0)subscript𝐾0subscript𝑄0K_{0}(Q_{0}) from 101010 to 161616, leads to an improvement in the performance of both the node-selection and weight-selection based FL frameworks. However, when we further increase K0​(Q0)subscript𝐾0subscript𝑄0K_{0}(Q_{0}) to 181818 and 202020, the performance of both frameworks begins to decline, demonstrating that there indeed exists a tradeoff between the model misfit loss and the communication error loss, as indicated by (29) and (59). Moreover, we can also observe that the performance of the weight-selection based FL framework is robust to the increase of Q0subscript𝑄0Q_{0}. In other words, we can randomly pick a value between 101010 and 181818 for Q0subscript𝑄0Q_{0} without significantly compromising the learning performance.

Fig. 5 shows the test accuracy (after L=100𝐿100L=100 training rounds) w.r.t. SNR. It can be observed from this figure that when increasing SNR from 50 dB to 70 dB, the learning performances of both node-selection and weight-selection based FL frameworks improve; the reason is that the communication errors decrease as SNR increases. Moreover, the weight-selection based FL framework outperforms its node-selection based counterpart, especially when SNR is low. We can also observe from this figure that when SNR=70SNR70\textsf{SNR}=70 dB, the performance of the all-node selection scheme improves significantly compared to that when SNR=50SNR50\textsf{SNR}=50 dB. The all-node selection scheme even outperforms the node-selection and weight-selection based frameworks when SNR=70SNR70\textsf{SNR}=70 dB, which means that we should select more edge nodes (i.e., larger K0subscript𝐾0K_{0}) or assign more edge nodes a large weight coefficient (i.e., larger Q0subscript𝑄0Q_{0}) in model aggregation when SNR is sufficiently high. That is the reason why the high and low SNR regions are respectively termed data limited and SNR limited regions in literature [11].

Fig. 6 shows test accuracy w.r.t. coherence time of wireless links, which is evaluated by the number of FL training rounds, i.e., O𝑂O. It can be observed from this figure that when the wireless links change slowly, i.e., O=100𝑂100O=100, the node-selection based FL framework performs worse than its all-node selection based counterpart, though the former outperforms the latter when O=1𝑂1O=1. The reason can be explained as follows. When {hd,k,j}subscriptℎ𝑑𝑘𝑗\{h_{d,k,j}\}, {𝒉r,k,j}subscript𝒉𝑟𝑘𝑗\{\bm{h}_{r,k,j}\}, and {𝒛j}subscript𝒛𝑗\{\bm{z}_{j}\} remain constant during O=100𝑂100O=100 training rounds, the selected edge nodes in each FL round remain the same. In other words, some edge nodes are never involved in the FL learning process, and thus their unique data samples are discarded forever, which inevitably degrades the learning performance. This explains why complicated edge node scheduling algorithms are often needed in node-selection based FL systems [34, 35]. In contrast, since all edge nodes are allowed to participate in model aggregation, the weight-selection based FL framework performs similarly in both O=1𝑂1O=1 and O=100𝑂100O=100.

Furthermore, as the number of edge nodes increases, clear enhancement in the performance of both the node-selection based and weight-selection based frameworks is observed, as depicted in Fig. 7. However, it is worth noting that the weight-selection based framework consistently outperforms its node-selection based counterpart. Specifically, when the total number of edge nodes is set to 101010, 151515, and 202020, and 80%percent8080\% of them are selected in the node-selection based framework, the weight-selection based framework exhibits performance gains of 10.12%percent10.1210.12\%, 6.26%percent6.266.26\%, and 2.35%percent2.352.35\%, respectively.

VII Conclusions

In this paper, we have studied the AirComp-empowered model aggregation approach for IRS-assisted FL systems. We first considered the conventional node-selection based FL framework, analyzed its convergence, derived an upper bound on its performance, and introduced how to optimize the selected edge nodes, along with their transmit equalization coefficients, the IRS phase shifts, and the receive factors of the cloud server to minimize the MSE. We further proposed a weight-selection based FL framework to avoid the noticeable decrease in the learning performance caused by node selection. In such a framework, we assigned each edge node an optimized weight coefficient in model aggregation instead of discarding any of them. The theoretical analyses and numerical experiments revealed that the weight-selection based FL framework was superior to its node-selection based counterpart. Moreover, though both frameworks had a tradeoff between the achieved MSE and the fraction of data involved in learning, the weight-selection based framework was more robust to changes in the fraction of data.

F​(𝒘⋆)𝐹superscript𝒘⋆\displaystyle F(\bm{w}^{\star}) ≤F​(𝒘[L+1])≤F​(𝒘[1])−a02​ρ​∑l=1L‖∇F​(𝒘[l])‖2absent𝐹superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝐿1𝐹superscript𝒘delimited-[]1subscript𝑎02𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙2\displaystyle\leq F(\bm{w}^{[L+1]})\leq F(\bm{w}^{[1]})-\frac{a_{0}}{2\rho}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{L}\left\|\nabla F(\bm{w}^{[l]})\right\|^{2}
+4​γ1​Lρ​(1−K0K)2+1ρ​∑l=1L‖𝒆2[l]‖2.4subscript𝛾1𝐿𝜌superscript1subscript𝐾0𝐾21𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒆2delimited-[]𝑙2\displaystyle+\frac{4\gamma_{1}L}{\rho}\left(1-\frac{K_{0}}{K}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{\rho}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{L}\big{\|}\bm{e}_{2}^{[l]}\big{\|}^{2}. (70)

After slight manipulations, we have

1L​∑l=1L‖∇F​(𝒘[l])‖21𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒘delimited-[]𝑙2\displaystyle\frac{1}{L}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{L}\left\|\nabla F(\bm{w}^{[l]})\right\|^{2} ≤2​ρa0​L​[F​(𝒘[1])−F​(𝒘⋆)]absent2𝜌subscript𝑎0𝐿delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝒘delimited-[]1𝐹superscript𝒘⋆\displaystyle\leq\frac{2\rho}{a_{0}L}[F(\bm{w}^{[1]})-F(\bm{w}^{\star})] (71)
+8​γ1a0​(1−K0K)2+2a0​L​∑l=1L‖𝒆2[l]‖2.8subscript𝛾1subscript𝑎0superscript1subscript𝐾0𝐾22subscript𝑎0𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒆2delimited-[]𝑙2\displaystyle+\frac{8\gamma_{1}}{a_{0}}\left(1-\frac{K_{0}}{K}\right)^{2}+\frac{2}{a_{0}L}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{L}\big{\|}\bm{e}_{2}^{[l]}\big{\|}^{2}.

Taking expectation on both sides of (71), we can obtain (2) and complete the proof.

Appendix C

Once 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} and 𝒮𝒮\cal S are given, we can simplify P1subscriptP1{\textsf{P}}_{1} as

minx,{xj}subscript𝑥subscript𝑥𝑗\displaystyle\min\limits_{x,\{x_{j}\}} x𝑥\displaystyle x (72a)

1N​∑j=1Nβk,jxj​|he,k,j|2≤1,∀k∈𝒮,formulae-sequence1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑒𝑘𝑗21for-all𝑘𝒮\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\frac{\beta_{k,j}}{x_{j}\left|h_{e,k,j}\right|^{2}}\leq 1,~{}\forall k\in{\cal S},

where we have defined xj=|mj|2subscript𝑥𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑗2x_{j}=|m_{j}|^{2}, ∀j∈𝒩for-all𝑗𝒩\forall j\in{\cal N}, and x=max⁡{xj}𝑥subscript𝑥𝑗x=\max\{x_{j}\}. Then, we write the Lagrange of (72) as

where μj≥0subscript𝜇𝑗0\mu_{j}\geq 0, and νk≥0subscript𝜈𝑘0\nu_{k}\geq 0, are the associated Lagrange multipliers. Then, the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition for (C) are given by

∂ℒ∂x=1−∑j=1Nμj=0;ℒ𝑥1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝜇𝑗0\displaystyle\frac{\partial{\cal L}}{\partial x}=1-\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\mu_{j}=0; (74a)

μj≥0,∀j∈𝒩;formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑗0for-all𝑗𝒩\displaystyle\mu_{j}\geq 0,~{}\forall j\in{\cal N}; (74d)

Suppose that there exists an xl<xsubscript𝑥𝑙𝑥x_{l}<x, ∃l∈𝒩𝑙𝒩\exists l\in{\cal N}. According to (74c), we have μl=0subscript𝜇𝑙0\mu_{l}=0. As a result, we obtain

∑k∈𝒮νkN​βk,lxl2​|he,k,l|2=μl=0,subscript𝑘𝒮subscript𝜈𝑘𝑁subscript𝛽𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑥2𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑒𝑘𝑙2subscript𝜇𝑙0\sum\limits_{k\in\cal S}\frac{\nu_{k}}{N}\frac{\beta_{k,l}}{x^{2}_{l}\left|h_{e,k,l}\right|^{2}}=\mu_{l}=0, (75)

which implies that νk=0subscript𝜈𝑘0\nu_{k}=0, ∀k∈𝒮for-all𝑘𝒮\forall k\in\cal S.

On the other hand, according to (74a), at least one of μ1,⋯,μNsubscript𝜇1⋯subscript𝜇𝑁\mu_{1},\cdots,\mu_{N} should be larger than zero, e.g., μp>0subscript𝜇𝑝0\mu_{p}>0, where p∈𝒩/{l}𝑝𝒩𝑙p\in{\cal N}/\{l\}. Recalling (74b), we have

∑k∈𝒮νkN​βk,pxp2​|he,k,p|2=μp>0.subscript𝑘𝒮subscript𝜈𝑘𝑁subscript𝛽𝑘𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑥2𝑝superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑒𝑘𝑝2subscript𝜇𝑝0\sum\limits_{k\in\cal S}\frac{\nu_{k}}{N}\frac{\beta_{k,p}}{x^{2}_{p}\left|h_{e,k,p}\right|^{2}}=\mu_{p}>0. (76)

It can be observed from (76) that at least one νksubscript𝜈𝑘\nu_{k} should be larger than zero, which contradicts with the previous conclusion that νk=0subscript𝜈𝑘0\nu_{k}=0, ∀k∈𝒮for-all𝑘𝒮\forall k\in\cal S. Thus, we have proven that xl<xsubscript𝑥𝑙𝑥x_{l}<x cannot exist, i.e., x1=⋯=xN=xsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑁𝑥x_{1}=\cdots=x_{N}=x. Moreover, recall the power constraint that

1N​∑j=1Nβk,jxj​|he,k,j|2=1N​∑j=1Nβk,jx​|he,k,j|2≤1,∀k∈𝒮.formulae-sequence1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗subscript𝑥𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑒𝑘𝑗21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑒𝑘𝑗21for-all𝑘𝒮\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\frac{\beta_{k,j}}{x_{j}\left|h_{e,k,j}\right|^{2}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\frac{\beta_{k,j}}{x\left|h_{e,k,j}\right|^{2}}\leq 1,~{}\forall k\in{\cal S}. (77)

Consequently, we have

x≥1N​∑j=1Nβk,j|he,k,j|2,∀k∈𝒮,formulae-sequence𝑥1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝛽𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑒𝑘𝑗2for-all𝑘𝒮x\geq\frac{1}{N}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\frac{\beta_{k,j}}{\left|h_{e,k,j}\right|^{2}},~{}\forall k\in{\cal S}, (78)

which completes the proof.
